review.title: It's about time: Online Macrotask Sequencing in Expert Crowdsourcing
review.abstract: We introduce the problem of Task Assignment and Sequencing (TAS), which adds the timeline perspective to expert crowdsourcing optimization. Expert crowdsourcing involves macrotasks, like document writing, product design, or web development, which take more time than typical binary microtasks, require expert skills, assume varying degrees of knowledge over a topic, and require crowd workers to build on each other's contributions. Current works usually assume offline optimization models, which consider worker and task arrivals known and do not take into account the element of time. Realistically however, time is critical: tasks have deadlines, expert workers are available only at specific time slots, and worker/task arrivals are not known a-priori. Our work is the first to address the problem of optimal task sequencing for online, heterogeneous, time-constrained macrotasks. We propose tas-online, an online algorithm that aims to complete as many tasks as possible within budget, required quality and a given timeline, without future input information regarding job release dates or worker availabilities. Results, comparing tas-online to four typical benchmarks, show that it achieves more completed jobs, lower flow times and higher job quality. This work has practical implications for improving the Quality of Service of current crowdsourcing platforms, allowing them to offer cost, quality and time improvements for expert tasks.

sections.text: We present the problem of Task Assignment and Sequencing (TAS), which adds a timeline perspective to expert optimization in crowdsourcing. Expert crowdsourcing includes macro activities such as document writing, product design, or web development, which take more time than typical binary micro-activities, require expert skills, require varying degrees of knowledge about a topic, and require crowdworkers to build on each other's contributions. Current work is typically based on offline optimization models that take into account known job and task requests and do not take into account the element of time. However, realistically, time is critical: tasks have deadlines, specialists are only available at specific times, and job / task requests are not a priori known. Our work is the first to address the problem of optimal task sequencing for online tasks and heterogeneous, time-limited macro-activities. We suggest tas-online job completion, an online algorithm that allows for performing tasks within a given task, as many as is possible, without improving the budget.

sections.heading: 3.4 TAS: An allocation problem with two aspects
sections.text: The TAS optimization problem combines aspects of two well-studied problems of different kinds, reflecting on the one hand the allocation of resources by workers and on the other hand the allocation of time frames.

sections.heading: 3.4.1 Allocation of Workers: The Multiple Knapsack perspective
sections.text: Considering only the labor allocation in our model, we can understand any job j of domain k with budget Cj as a knapsack of this size, which we need to fill with the expertise of workers eik. Since the availability of labor limits how often a single worker can be packed, we have a limited version of the multiple knapsack problem [25]. The difference from this classic problem is the optimization goal. While in TAS we want to maximize the number of jobs done in terms of their individual quality thresholds Qj, the goal in multiple knapsack is to maximize the sum of all the packed expertise, no matter how it is distributed among the different knapsack.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we introduce TAS, a model that adds the timeline and online perspective to the optimization of task assignments in expert crowdsourcing. Using a greedy scheduling algorithm, tas-online, we show that optimization in this model can significantly improve the performance of expert crowdsourcing. Future enhancements to enable the TAS model to handle other challenging settings include: additional budget flexibility, prioritization of jobs and / or workers, fine-tuning the aggregation mechanism for job quality, variability of work performance over time, and multiple orders per worker / time window.

metadata.abstractText: We introduce the problem of Task Assignment and Sequencing (TAS), which adds the timeline perspective to expert crowdsourcing optimization. Expert crowdsourcing involves macrotasks, like document writing, product design, or web development, which take more time than typical binary microtasks, require expert skills, assume varying degrees of knowledge over a topic, and require crowd workers to build on each other’s contributions. Current works usually assume offline optimization models, which consider worker and task arrivals known and do not take into account the element of time. Realistically however, time is critical: tasks have deadlines, expert workers are available only at specific time slots, and worker/task arrivals are not known a-priori. Our work is the first to address the problem of optimal task sequencing for online, heterogeneous, time-constrained macrotasks. We propose tas-online, an online algorithm that aims to complete as many tasks as possible within budget, required quality and a given timeline, without future input information regarding job release dates or worker availabilities. Results, comparing tas-online to four typical benchmarks, show that it achieves more completed jobs, lower flow times and higher job quality. This work has practical implications for improving the Quality of Service of current crowdsourcing platforms, allowing them to offer cost, quality and time improvements for expert tasks.
